words.definition: If something is amid something else, then it is in the middle of it.
words.example: The tower stood tall amid the surrounding hills.

words.definition: Backstage is the area behind the stage in a theater.
words.example: After the play, the actors went backstage to change their clothes.

words.definition: A billionaire is a person who has at least one billion dollars.
words.example: The billionaire donated a lot of money to the hospital.

words.definition: A brute is a person who is mean and sometimes violent.
words.example: The bully was a brute who always picked on smaller kids.

words.definition: If someone is clumsy, then they move in an awkward way.
words.example: The clumsy boy tripped and fell on his way to school.

words.definition: To collide with something means to hit it while moving.
words.example: The two cars collided at the intersection.

words.definition: A culprit is a person who has done something wrong or illegal.
words.example: The police finally caught the culprit who stole the money.

words.definition: To evacuate means to leave a place of danger and go to a safer place.
words.example: The people were told to evacuate their homes before the storm.

words.definition: If something is flammable, it can catch fire easily.
words.example: Be careful with those matches; the curtains are flammable.

words.definition: A mob is a large, often angry, group of people.
words.example: An angry mob gathered outside the government building.

words.definition: If something is premature, it happens before it is supposed to.
words.example: The baby's birth was premature, so he stayed in the hospital.

words.definition: To resent something means to feel angry about it.
words.example: She resented the fact that she had to work on the weekend.

words.definition: A satire is a way of criticizing something using humor.
words.example: The movie was a satire about the world of fashion.

words.definition: Scrutiny is the careful examination of something.
words.example: The plan was under close scrutiny by the committee.

words.definition: To segregate means to keep one group of people apart from another.
words.example: The school was segregated, so the boys and girls were in different classes.

words.definition: To subject means to make someone experience something unpleasant.
words.example: The prisoners were subjected to harsh conditions.

words.definition: To testify means to give evidence as a witness in a court of law.
words.example: The witness was asked to testify in the trial.

words.definition: A tumult is a state of noisy confusion or excitement.
words.example: There was a tumult in the streets after the team won.

words.definition: To underestimate means to think something is smaller or less important than it is.
words.example: Don't underestimate the power of the wind.

words.definition: An uproar is a lot of noise or excitement caused by people.
words.example: The announcement caused an uproar among the crowd.
